text: uh hi everyone big thingy cough tano
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review
of this new lil baby and a little dirk
project
the voice of the heroes this is a new
collaboration between two of the biggest
names in modern rap that is a little
baby and a little dirk
lil dirk is a singer and rapper who came
out of chicago's legendary drill scene
in the 2010s
and despite label and legal issues has
managed to stay pretty prolific over the
past decade but with the release
of his record the voice in 2020 he seems
to have hit
a moment of career clarity like a second
wind if you will
he even landed a hot feature with drake
on that laugh now cry later track in
then lil babies in atlanta native a
quality control artist and
admittedly not someone who i've reviewed
well in the past
between my turn and his drip harder
record with gunna
there have been a couple of not goods
and i guess for good personal reason i
mean up to this point i have not been
a little baby fan by any stretch of the
imagination saw him as kind of a thugger
and future clone
the auto tune he often mixes with his
voice doesn't really go with the warbly
timbre
i haven't found a lot of substance to
his songs over the years as well
but in the midst of last year he kind of
turned a
bit of a new leaf which i think you
could at least partially attribute to
the release of his track the bigger
picture
which was dropped in reaction to the
murder of george floyd and the
protests that followed which may have
not been the best produced song in the
world but certainly
when it came to lyrics and substance was
one of the most profound tracks
on this topic at that time when we look
at the greater pantheon
of modern rappers i think most people
would have assumed
that uh in that moment we would have had
that type of track that would have
dominated the scene and dominated the
message from kendrick or
cole or literally a hundred other
rappers before little baby is even in
the discussion
but no it was little baby it was little
baby who did that
so with both these guys coming together
at interesting points in their career
they are now delivering to us 18 tracks
where i think
for the most part lyrically and vocally
they're in top
form maybe they're feeling revitalized
or in a way they're bringing out the
best in each other either way i've never
heard
either of these guys in a solo capacity
sounding this good
as on one track after another we have
inspiring stories of struggle
street life overcoming adversity and
navigating the treacherous world of
the rap game and the legal system
sometimes these themes come
through on incredibly focused and
passionate tracks like the
melodic and anthemic rich off pain with
a rod wave there's also the aspirational
make it out as well as
which goes over the trauma of bullets
flying poverty overdue bills and
paranoia but even when dirk and baby go
general
topically on some of these tracks their
passion their energy as well as vivid
descriptions of their life experiences
comes through
which is honestly just refreshing
because with the exception of a few
tracks
it seems like these two are just not
taking this record very lightly for
every point on this lp where a little
baby is really wrapping his ass off lil
dirk is
singing his ass off which is kind of
what makes them such a dream team on
this project
since between the two of them we have
some pretty essential bases covered
whether that's on an introspective
moment here or a total banger like lying
or
2040. now having said this though i'm
not trying to sell this record as like
the most
groundbreaking or adventurous lp under
the sun
aesthetically this thing checks a lot of
the same boxes that recent releases from
baby and dirk have
many releases in fact from the
mainstream mello trap world
so if that's not your vibe this may
still not really be for you
but for me the voice of the hero shows
two leading artists in their field
taking very seriously a strain of
hip-hop that
in the studio a lot of recording artists
a lot of rappers
approach more casually with maybe more
of a quantity over quality mindset which
i can't really get too mad at in the
grander scheme of things since
audiences and the music industry at
large pretty much
reward and encourage that sort of output
pump out as many tracks as possible and
whatever stick sticks
but it really does sound like baby and
dirk are putting a lot of thought into
some of the messages they're trying to
get across
on this record as well as the song
structures here too because there are
numerous hooks that kind of pop but as
impressed as i am
with this lp as much as it exceeded my
expectations
it does come with its very glaring flaws
there's a kind of redundant feature from
travis scott on this record where
flow wise and melodically he doesn't
really bring anything that dirk or baby
didn't already bring to the song early
on
meanwhile there's a young thug feature
on here too that's maybe a little too
mild low-key
easily one of the most forgettable
appearances of anyone on this record
then there's the production
which for the most part is super plain
just kind of gets the job done i suppose
for sure there are some blemishes here
and there like
maybe a hi-hat is abnormally high or
something or some keys some musical
addition to a track will be so faint and
so quiet in the background it might as
well
just not be there but really my biggest
issue with the 18 cuts on this project
is just how
little aesthetic and musical variety
there is amongst these beats
between the keyboard patches and the
perks and the 808s and
geez i just feel like i'm stuck in a
maze where every turn that i take
at every every corner is just like
sounding or looking the same
which is weird because i know a host of
different producers put this record
together i'm hearing a variety of
different producer tags throughout the
lp
but honestly if you stripped them all
out and told me that like two three guys
produced the whole thing
i'd have to believe you for a record
that's like an hour long
i wish wish wish that dirk and baby just
got
a little more ambitious with the
instrumentals they chose and
even on the rare occasion where they are
taking a slight risk like on that's
facts for example
the beat is a little too spaced out and
awkward then there's also the matter of
mixing
on these tracks because oddly enough
there are numerous songs here where
dirk's voice is just so much bolder and
louder than babies
this to a degree could have to do with
presentation
vocal style timbre range as well as
auto-tune application
so there are some logical reasons as to
why one artist's voice may not pop in
the mixes
as much as another's but still there are
tracks like lying for example where for
whatever reason lil baby just doesn't
sound like his volume is as high
and to speak to the auto-tune thing for
a second while i do appreciate it's a
trademark piece of little baby sound i
do feel like there are pockets on this
record where he's pushing things so hard
lyrically
that he's almost reaching like a bit of
a limit with it where the auto-tune is
becoming like a detriment to the message
he's trying to get across
but still i find it pretty interesting
that someone in this lane who
many people who are old heads with that
sort of mindset might see as a mumble
rapper
is like really packing some serious
content into his stuff and as much as i
can appreciate this record and praise it
on the content side on the writing side
on the performance side aesthetically
and musically it's just a little too
one note to blow me away from end to end
feeling a decent too strong
